unicode.value:
Let's talk about what we have done so far!

Let's learn how we can talk about our experiences and answer these questions.

Survey

In this lesson you will learn how to talk about the things you have done in your life with the Present Perfect. Also, you will practice this tense with the adverbs ever and never.

By the end of the lesson you will be able to express:Â 

  • Affirmative sentences
  • Negative sentences
  • Yes/No Questions

All in Present Perfect Simple!Â 

Let's learn!
What do I need to know?

For this lesson you need to know the PastÂ Participle Form of the verbs.

If you have not seen that topic, you should choose a different activity.Â 

You can come back after you have learned that form of the verbs!

The Present Perfect Simple helps us to express different things,Â but in this lesson we will focus on one function.

We use the Present Perfect to talk about past experiences up to this moment. For example:

  • I have seen a baby koala. (at some point in the past of my life)
  • She has been in Egypt.

Here the exact time of the event is not important, so do not use specific past time expressions such as yesterday, at 3:00 p.m., in 2010, etc.

The Present Perfect is formed by two parts. Look at more examples:

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â 

Donât get confused, the verb have is an auxiliary for this tense. Then, we have theÂ Â Past Perfect form of theÂ main verbÂ (in these examples are travel-traveled and see-seen). So, the structure is:

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â 

It is possible to contract the personal pronouns with the verb have: I've traveled, You've traveled, She's traveled, We've traveled, They've traveled.

On the contrary, if we want to say that we have not done something in our lives, we add the negative particle after have. We can contract it too.

Â  Â  Â Examples:

Â  Â  Â We have not eaten Chinese food.Â 

Â  Â  Â He hasn't failed an exam.

You can also use the adverbÂ "never" to say that you have not done something previously, but if you use never, the sentence has to be affirmative:Â 

They have never traveled by plane.

NOT: They have not never traveled by plane.

For yes/no questions invert the auxiliary and the subject:

Have you swum in the sea? Yes, I have. / No, I havenât.

Has she tried bungee-jumping?Â Yes, she has. / No, she hasnât.

It is common to use the adverb "ever" in this type of questions. Ever means at any time of our life. For example:

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â 

Have they ever been to Australia? They have never been there.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.

Provide instruction on how the dropdown activity should be completed.
Roger and Ter are looking at a touristic brochure. Choose the correct option to complete the conversation.

Roger: Look, whales are majestic. Have you ever Â seen a whale?

Ter:Â Well, I have seen Â them in documentaries, but not in real life.Â  Have you ever swum with dolphins?

Roger: Yes I have. It was amazing! I would like to go diving.

Ter:Â Oh it's fantastic, my boyfriend and I have tried Â it and it's very exciting. Has your family visited the city's aquarium?Â 

Roger: I have never visited the aquarium, we could goÂ next summer!

Ter: Yes! I haven't gone either. I have heard that there are all kinds of fish.

To select words to choose, double click on the word to select it and click on the 'Hide/Show' button below.

Use | (the vertical bar) to separate words.

DropDown exercises are texts or sentences where students must select the correct words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Choose words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge
If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.

Annie had to write a text for homework. She had to write the things she has done before, but she made some mistakes. Read her homework and find five mistakes. Then correct them, write the correct word in the squares.
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

Â  Â  Â  2. have

Â  Â  Â  5. haven't

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.

Remember the following key points. Order them so they follow this structure: 1. Use of the Present Perfect 2.Time that the Present Perfect refers to 3. Structure 4. Negation 5. Questions

  • We use the Present Perfect to talk about past experiences. 
  • The exact time of the action is not important.
  • We form the Present Perfect with the auxiliary "have" in present and the main verb is in past participle.
  • Besides "not" we can use "never" in affirmative sentences. It means that we have not done something in our life.
  • We can add "ever" that means at some point in our life.

Check

Correct!

Sorry, it's not correct!

If you remember all the points mentioned above, you succeeded in this lesson!Â Can you answer the questions of the beginning and ask them to your classmates now?

Where have you traveled?

Have you ever done something dangerous?

What's the funniest thing you have ever done?

10:00

Â  Â  Â  Â  2. In order not to lose points, it is important to check not only your answer but your spelling too.
